{{Infobox sports award | name = Coupe Aéronautique Gordon Bennett | current_event = | image = [[File:CoupeGordonBennet1906.jpg|200px|alt=A silver statue of a gas balloon]] | sport = [[Gas balloon]]ing | competition = | discipline = | givenfor = | english = Gordon Bennett Cup | localnames = | nickname = | first = September 30, 1906 | number = 62 | last = | firstwinner = [[Frank Purdy Lahm]] | mostwins = [[Vincent Leys]] (nine) | mostrecent = Mateusz Rękas, Jacek Bogdański (2018) }} The '''Gordon Bennett Cup''' (or {{lang|fr|Coupe Aéronautique Gordon Bennett}}) is the world's oldest [[gas balloon]] race, and is "regarded as the premier event of world balloon racing" according to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.<ref name=nyt/><ref name=latimes/> Referred to as the "[[Blue ribbon|Blue Ribbon]]" of aeronautics, the first race started from [[Paris]], France, on September 30, 1906.<ref>{{Cite news| url = http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200067.html |work=[[Flight Global]]|page=69| date=January 30, 1909|accessdate=September 27, 2010|title = Aero Club of the United Kingdom — Official notices to members — Gordon-Bennett Aeronautical Race, 1909}}</ref> The event was sponsored by [[James Gordon Bennett, Jr.]], the millionaire sportsman and owner of the ''[[New York Herald]]'' newspaper.<ref name=official>{{Cite web|url=http://www.coupegordonbennett.org/ |publisher=[[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] |title=The Coupe Aéronautique Gordon Bennett |accessdate=September 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101009101601/http://www.coupegordonbennett.org/ |archivedate=October 9, 2010 |df= }}</ref> According to the organizers, the aim of the contest "is simple: to fly the furthest distance from the launch site."<ref name=official/> The contest ran from 1906 to 1938, interrupted by [[World War I]] and in 1931, but was suspended in 1939 when the hosts, Poland, were invaded at the start of [[World War II]]. The event was not resurrected until 1979, when American Tom Heinsheimer, an atmospheric physicist, gained permission from the holders to host the trophy.<ref name=resurrect>{{Cite web |url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1095034/1/index.htm | title = A Bunch Of Basket Cases| first=Joe|last=Jares|accessdate=October 5, 2010|date=June 11, 1979|work = [[Sports Illustrated]]| publisher=[[Time Inc]]}}</ref> The competition was not officially reinstated by the [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] (FAI) until 1983.<ref name=minutes>{{Cite web | url = http://www.fai.org/ballooning/system/files/CIA-Policy-Manual-to-1997.doc | format = doc | accessdate = October 5, 2010 | title = CIA Policy Manual | date = June 1997 | page = C6/6 | quote = The First Official Gordon Bennett Cup race since 1938 will take place on 26 June 1983, from Place de la Concorde in Paris, the same spot where the first race started on September 30th 1906. | publisher = [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110809181951/http://www.fai.org/ballooning/system/files/CIA-Policy-Manual-to-1997.doc | archivedate = 9 August 2011 | df = }}</ref>
The record time for the winner of the event is held by Germans Wilhelm Eimers and Bernd Landsmann who remained airborne for over 92 hours in the 1995 race,<ref name=winning>{{Cite web | url = http://www.coupegordonbennett.org/system/files/CIA-GB-Winning-Pilots.xls | title = Winning pilots and co-pilots (alphabetic list) | accessdate = September 27, 2010 | publisher = [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] | format = [[Microsoft Excel|xls]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101008041306/http://www.coupegordonbennett.org/system/files/CIA-GB-Winning-Pilots.xls | archivedate = October 8, 2010 | df = }}</ref> taking off from Switzerland and landing four days later in Latvia. The distance record is held by the Belgian duo of Bob Berben and Benoît Siméons who, in 2005, piloted their balloon {{convert|3400|km|sp=us}} from [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]], United States, to [[Saint-Michel-du-Squatec, Quebec|Squatec, Quebec]], Canada.<ref name=winning/> The most successful pilot is French [[Vincent Leys]] who won the trophy nine times between 1997 and 2017, while American teams have won on the most occasions, with twelve victories.
The 2010 competition started in the United Kingdom, with the balloons departing from [[Bristol]] on September 25. The race was marred by the disappearance of the American team during a storm over the Adriatic Sea on October 1.<ref name=calledoff>{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-11471461 | title = Italian coastguards call off search for US balloonists| date = October 4, 2010| accessdate=October 4, 2010| publisher = [[BBC News]]}}</ref> The balloon was missing until December 6, when a fishing vessel found the cabin containing the pilots' bodies off the coast of Italy.<ref name=foundBBC>{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11925697 | title = Bodies of missing US balloonists found off Italy| date = December 6, 2010| accessdate=December 6, 2010|publisher = [[BBC News]]}}</ref> The 2013 event, departing from France and landing in Portugal, was again won by the French in ''F-PPGB''.<ref name="2013results" />
==Rules== According to the official rules, the competition is open to all National Aero Clubs (NACs) "who have met their obligations to the FAI", with each NAC being allowed to enter up to three teams whose pilots are of the same nationality as the NAC.<ref name=rules>{{Cite web| url=http://www.fai.org/ballooning/system/files/CIA-GB-MER-2010.doc| format=doc| title=Model Event Rules for Coupe Aéronautique Gordon Bennett| year=2010| accessdate=September 28, 2010| publisher=[[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]]| page=2| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809180044/http://www.fai.org/ballooning/system/files/CIA-GB-MER-2010.doc| archivedate=August 9, 2011| df=}}</ref> Before this, only two teams from any single NAC were permitted to compete in a single competition.<ref name=story1983/> Pilots should have at least 50 hours experience as pilot in command and be authorized for night-time flying. At least one member of each team must be capable of communicating with Air Traffic Control in English.<ref name=rules/>
The team who wins the contest receives the Coupe Aéronautique Gordon Bennett trophy and the team's NAC will hold the contest two years later (originally the winning NAC would host the competition the following year). Any NAC winning the cup in three consecutive races will be the final holder of the cup with the subsequent option to offer a new cup.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.fai.org/ballooning/system/files/CIA-GB-MER-2010.doc| format=doc| title=Model Event Rules for Coupe Aéronautique Gordon Bennett| year=2010| accessdate=September 28, 2010| publisher=[[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]]| pages=5, 10–11| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809180044/http://www.fai.org/ballooning/system/files/CIA-GB-MER-2010.doc| archivedate=August 9, 2011| df=}}</ref>
==Unofficial events== Resurrected in 1979 by American [[Tom Heinsheimer]], the competition was held without official FAI sanction for four years. [[Ben Abruzzo]] and [[Maxie Anderson]] secured victory piloting Double Eagle III {{convert|987|km|sp=us}} in 47 hours from California to Colorado.<ref name=resurrect/> The following year, the winning team of Jerry Tepper and Corky Myers floated {{convert|862|km|sp=us}} from the takeoff point in California.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=n6ISAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_vYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6571,1358180&dq=gordon+bennett&hl=en | title = 2 Denver pilots win Gordon Bennett race | work = [[The Bulletin (Bend)|The Bulletin]] |location=[[Bend, Oregon]]| accessdate= October 5, 2010| date = April 30, 1980| page=43}}</ref> The 1981 race was won again by Abruzzo, with different co-pilot Rocky Aoki, who covered {{convert|2168|km|sp=us}} before touching down,<ref name=eightyonetwo/> while the 1982 race was won by [[Joe Kittinger]] and Charles Knapp who piloted Rosie O'Grady {{convert|1423|km|sp=us}}.<ref name=eightyonetwo>{{Cite web | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=THgUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pgIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6858,7131960&dq=gordon-bennett+1980+balloon&hl=en | title = Balloonists' 884-Mile Flight Is Tops In Endurance Race | work = [[Toledo Blade]] | publisher = [[Block Communications]]| accessdate= October 5, 2010 | date = May 10, 1982 | page=12}}</ref> Heinsheimer attempted to gain the copyright over the name "Gordon Bennett" and run the event without FAI sanction. However the FAI were granted exclusive rights to the name in 1983, and the organization officially reinstated the competition later that year.<ref name=minutes/> Heinsheimer went on to arrange further contests in the United States which were still reported in the national press as being the "Gordon Bennett Balloon Race" or similar.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aWoRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=F-EDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2980,1404155 | title = Winner declared in balloon race| work = [[The Register-Guard]] | location= [[Eugene, Oregon]]| date = May 6, 1986 | accessdate=October 7, 2010| page = 3A}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1PgPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FI8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6777,4367813 | title = Rosie O'Grady wins balloon race | work = [[Ellensburg Daily Record]]| accessdate = October 7, 2010 | date = May 3, 1988 | page=9}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/66585445.html?dids=66585445:66585445&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT | title = Rolling Hills Official Nudges Soviets to an Uplifting Venture Ballooning: The Soviet Union gets its first taste of the sport in a competitive, international venue and a glimpse at its research application.| work = Los Angeles Times | first=Ann |last=Johnson|date = October 28, 1989 | page = 28}}</ref>
== Incidents == [[File:Conqueror draped over houses of Berlin 1908.jpg|thumb|Conqueror draped over houses of Berlin 1908]] The 1908 race in Berlin saw the fall of the balloon Conqueror, flown by A. Holland Forbes and [[Augustus Post]]. Conqueror was the largest balloon entered in the race, standing 80 feet high and with a gas capacity of 80,000 cubic feet. Before the race Forbes had attempted to lengthen the balloon's appendix to give the team a strategic advantage. Instead the balloon hit a fence just after take off, lost two ballast bags, ascended rapidly and ripped open three minutes into the race. The pair slashed off ballast as they fell 3,000 feet. Their descent was slowed only as the balloon's fabric caught in the netting and formed a rough parachute. They took hold of the ring above them and lifted their feet as the basket smashed through the tiled roof of a house in the Berlin suburb of Friedenau. Both the men and their instruments survived intact.<ref>Post, Augustus (October 1908). [http://www.unz.org/Pub/Century-1910oct-00935?View=PDF "A Fall From the Sky"]. ''The Century Magazine'': 935–946 – via UNZ.org.</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Aeronauts Unhurt in 4,000 Foot Fall|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/11780317/aeronauts_unhurt_in_4000_foot_fall/|newspaper= The Washington Times=October 12, 1908|page=1|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = June 17, 2017 }} {{free access}}</ref> [[File:Hawley and Post following 1910 Gordon Bennett cup.png|thumb|Hawley and Post following 1910 Gordon Bennett Cup]] The winners of the 1910 Gordon Bennett Cup, [[Alan R. Hawley]] and [[Augustus Post]], set a distance and duration record of 1,173 miles in 44 hours and 25 minutes,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fai.org/gordonbennett/results|title=Results|last=Carrera|first=Faustine|website=www.fai.org|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-06-23}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> but the pair of experienced balloonists landed in a remote section of Canadian wilderness in Quebec. After a week passed with no word from the team, search parties were formed by the [[Aero Club of America]], but many newspapers reported that the men were likely dead. Instead they emerged after ten days, assisted by two local trappers who had been out on a hunting trip and happened to run into them. Hawley had injured a knee, but otherwise the pair were unharmed and received a hero's welcome upon their safe return.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j4tHAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA451&lpg=PA451&dq=%22A+record+voyage+in+the+air%22+augustus+post&source=bl&ots=6ALG7HT-zH&sig=lq2PS9XTIwaNroCYXbOaPjYWRe4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjbyuOtl5_UAhUB24MKHUuRBcoQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=%22A%20record%20voyage%20in%20the%20air%22%20augustus%20post&f=false|title=A Record Voyage in the Air|last=Post|first=Augustus|publisher=Century Illustrated Monthly Magazine|year=1911|isbn=|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref>
On September 23, 1923, five competitors were killed when they were struck by lightning while six more were injured in storms. Among the dead were Lieutenants John W. Choptaw and Robert S. Olmsted who were killed when their balloon "US Army S6" crashed in [[Loosbroek]], Netherlands.<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://www.bhic.nl/index.php?id=11607 |title = Luchtballon op Loosbroek | publisher = Brabants Historisch Informatie Centrum|language=Dutch|accessdate=March 3, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|year= 1925 |title = Scores of Lives Deliberately Risked and Sacrificed in Pursuit of Knowledge to Protect Others From Disease and Death | journal = Popular Mechanics|volume= 44|issue= July |pages=49–54 |publisher= Popular Mechanics Co|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=DtsDAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA49&lpg=RA1-PA49&dq=%22Scores+of+Lives+Deliberately+Risked+and+Sacrificed+in+Pursuit+of+Knowledge+to+Protect+Others+From+Disease+and+Death+%22#v=onepage&q=%22Scores%20of%20Lives%20Deliberately%20Risked%20and%20Sacrificed%20in%20Pursuit%20of%20Knowledge%20to%20Protect%20Others%20From%20Disease%20and%20Death%20%22&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://digital.hagley.org/u?/p268001coll33,35 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707095332/http://digital.hagley.org/u?/p268001coll33,35 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 7, 2012 |title=First photos of International Balloon Race which resulted in five deaths |publisher=Hagley Digital Archives |accessdate=March 8, 2011 }}</ref> Sixty years later, in 1983, Americans [[Maxie Anderson]] and Don Ida were killed as the gondola detached from their balloon during an attempt to avoid crossing into East German airspace.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4NQVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PBIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5661,17746&dq=maxie+anderson&hl=en | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151223114056/https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4NQVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PBIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5661,17746&dq=maxie+anderson&hl=en | dead-url = yes | archive-date = December 23, 2015 | work = [[The Milwaukee Sentinel]] | page = 3 | date = July 1, 1983 | accessdate = September 28, 2010 | title = Balloon tried to avoid border }}</ref> Anderson and Ida were participating in the "Coupe Charles et Robert" (named for [[Jacques Charles]] and the [[Robert brothers]], inventors of the gas balloon) which was run in parallel with the Gordon Bennett Cup. Following their deaths, the "Coupe Charles et Robert" was never run again.<ref name=story1983>{{Cite web| url=http://www.coupegordonbennett.org/system/files/CIA-GB-book-1983-story.doc| title=The 27th Gordon Bennett Race 1983| format=doc| accessdate=October 6, 2010| last=Hohmann Sr| first=Ulrich| publisher=[[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]]| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725202029/http://www.coupegordonbennett.org/system/files/CIA-GB-book-1983-story.doc| archivedate=July 25, 2011| df=}}</ref>
On September 12, 1995, three [[gas balloon]]s participating in the race entered [[Belarus]]ian air space. Despite the fact that competition organizers had informed the Belarusian Government about the race in May and that flight plans had been filed, a [[Mil Mi-24|Mil Mi-24B]] attack helicopter of the [[Belarusian Air Force]] shot down one balloon,<ref name=nyt>{{Cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/14/world/2-american-balloonists-die-when-shot-down-in-belarus.html| work =[[The New York Times]] | publisher = The New York Times Company| accessdate=September 28, 2010|date=September 14, 1995|title = 2 American Balloonists Die When Shot Down in Belarus|first=Malcolm W.|last=Browne}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://flightsafety.org/ap/ap_july96.pdf| format=pdf|publisher=[[Flight Safety Foundation]] | accessdate=September 28, 2010|date=July 1996 | title = Racing Balloon Is Shot Down by Attack Helicopter in Belarus}}</ref> killing two American citizens, Alan Fraenckel and John Stuart-Jervis.<ref name=latimes>{{Cite web | url = http://articles.latimes.com/1995-09-15/news/mn-46149_1_american-balloon | accessdate=September 28, 2010| date=September 15, 1995| title = Ill-Fated Balloonists Shared Passion for Flying| first=Marlene|last=Cimons|author2=Williams, Carol J.|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher = [[Tribune Company]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/belarus-shoots-down-us-balloon-1600976.html | work = [[The Independent]] | accessdate=September 28, 2010| date = September 14, 1995| title = Belarus shoots down US balloon}}</ref> Another of the balloons was forced to land while the third landed safely over two hours after the initial downing. The crews of the two balloons were fined for entering Belarus without a [[Visa (document)|visa]] and released. Belarus has neither apologized nor offered compensation for the deaths.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5371.htm | title = Belarus| publisher = [[United States Department of State]] | date= August 27, 2010| accessdate=September 28, 2010}}</ref>
On September 29, 2010, the 2004 trophy-winning American team of [[Richard Abruzzo]] and [[Carol Rymer Davis]] went missing in thunderstorms over the [[Adriatic Sea]].<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-11434556| publisher=[[BBC News]]| accessdate= September 30, 2010| date=September 29, 2010| title = Hydrogen race balloonists missing in Adriatic storm}}</ref> On September 30, the USA retrieval crew suggested that the balloon may have ditched in the sea or have been destroyed by lightning.<ref>{{Cite web |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-11448372 | title = Lightning may have struck missing balloonists' craft | date = September 30, 2010| accessdate=September 30, 2010| publisher = [[BBC News]]}}</ref> Debris was found on October 1 by search crews but race control determined that it was not from the missing balloon.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/10/01/missing.balloonists/?hpt=T2 | publisher = [[CNN]] | accessdate= October 1, 2010| title = Debris may not be of missing balloon | date = October 1, 2010 | first = Hada|last=Messia}}</ref> Despite this, organizers later stated that the final calculated rate of descent of the balloon had been about {{convert|50|mph}}, and that the team's survival was "unlikely".<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-11451314 | title = Gordon Bennett director 'pessimistic' about balloonists | date = October 1, 2010| accessdate=October 1, 2010| publisher = [[BBC News]]}}</ref> The search for the missing pair was called off on October 4.<ref name=calledoff/> The balloon's cabin containing the bodies was recovered by an Italian fishing boat on December 6.<ref name=foundBBC/>
==Official winners== '''Key'''

{{refimprove|date=December 2017}} [[File:USA declaration independence.jpg|thumb|left|200px|A copy of the [[United States Declaration of Independence]]]][[File:Gutenberg Bible.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A Gutenberg Bible printed in the 1450's on display at the US Library of Congress]] '''Historical documents''' are original [[document]]s that contain important historical information about a person, place, or event and can thus serve as [[primary sources]] as important ingredients of the [[historical method]]ology.
Significant historical documents can be [[deed]]s, laws, accounts of battles (often given by the victors or persons sharing their viewpoint), or the exploits of the powerful. Though these documents are of historical interest, they do not detail the daily lives of ordinary people, or the way society functioned. [[Anthropologist]]s, [[historians]] and [[archeologists]] generally are more interested in documents that describe the [[everyday life|day-to-day lives]] of ordinary people, indicating what they ate, their interaction with other members of their households and social groups, and their states of mind. It is this [[information]] that allows them to try to understand and describe the way society was functioning at any particular time in [[history]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prattlibrary.org/research/tools/index.aspx?cat=19963&id=83744|title=Exploring Daily Life throughout History: How Did They Live?|publisher=[[Enoch Pratt Free Library]]}}</ref> Greek [[ostraka]] provide good examples of historical documents from "among the [[common people]]".
Many documents that are produced today, such as personal letters, pictures, contracts, newspapers, and medical records, would be considered valuable historical documents in the [[future]]. However most of these will be lost in the future since they are either printed on ordinary paper which has a limited lifespan, or even stored in [[Digital data|digital]] formats, then lost track over time.
Some companies and government entities are attempting to increase the number of documents that will survive the passage of time, by taking into account the preservation issues, and either printing documents in a manner that would increase the likelihood of them surviving indefinitely, or placing selected documents in [[time capsule]]s or other special [[information storage|storage]] environments.

{{Infobox wrestling event |name = Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (2017) |image =Homenaje a Dos Leyendas 2017.png |caption =Official poster for the event |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date = March 17, 2017<ref name=H2L2017Announced>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-E5eyTiB8a0 | title=CMLL Informa 18 de Enero del 2017 | author=[[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] | language=Spanish | publisher=[[YouTube]] | date=January 18, 2017 | accessdate=January 19, 2017 | trans-title=CMLL Informat January 18, 2017}}</ref> |date_aired = |attendance = |venue = [[Arena México]] |city = [[Mexico City, Mexico]] |lastevent = [[CMLL Torneo Nacional de Parejas Increíbles (2017)]] |nextevent = [[CMLL Reyes del Aire#Reyes del Aire (2017)|Reyes del Aire]] (2017) |event = [[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas]] |lastevent2 = [[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (2016)]] |nextevent2 = [[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (2018)]] }} '''Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (2017)''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "Homage to Two Legends") was a major [[professional wrestling]] event produced and scripted by [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL; Spanish for "World Wrestling Council") that took place on March 17, 2016. The show, like all of CMLL's major shows took place in [[Arena México]], [[Mexico City, Mexico]], CMLL's home venue, nicknamed "the Cathedral of Lucha Libre". The 2017 event was the 23rd event in the [[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas]] series of shows. The event paid homage to CMLL founder [[Salvador Lutteroth]], who is always honored at ''Dos Leyendas'', as well as Arturo Díaz Mendoza, better known under the [[ring name]] [[Villano III]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/lucha-libre/2017/01/18/el-cmll-reconocera-al-villano-iii-en-homenaje-a-dos-leyendas | trans-titleCMLL will recognize Villano III at Homenaje a Dos Leyendas= | date=January 18, 2017 | accessdate=January 19, 2017 | language=Spanish | work=MedioTiempo | publisher=[[MSN]] | title=El CMLL reconocerá al Villano III en Homenaje a dos Leyendas}}}</ref>
The main event of the show was a ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'', or bet match, where [[Diamante Azul]] defeated [[Comandante Pierroth|Pierroth]], forcing Pierroth to unmask after the loss.. The Sky Team ([[Místico II|Místico]], [[Valiente (wrestler)|Valiente]] and [[Volador Jr]]) defend the [[CMLL World Trios Championship]] against [[Los Hijos del Infierno]] ([[Luciferno]] and [[Mephisto (wrestler)|Mephisto]]) and [[Hechicero]]. [[Último Guerrero]] successfully defended the [[NWA World Historic Middleweight Championship]] against [[Matt Taven]].
==Production== ===Background=== Since 1996 the Mexican [[wrestling promotion|wrestling company]] [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (Spanish for "World Wrestling Council"; CMLL) has held a show in March each year to commemorate the passing of CMLL founder [[Salvador Lutteroth]] who died in March 1987.<ref name=Lutteroth>{{cite book|title=Lucha Libre: Masked Superstars of Mexican Wrestling|publisher=Distributed Art Publishers, Inc.|year=2005|chapter=Los Lutteroth / the Lutteroths|pages=20–27|isbn=968-6842-48-9}}</ref> For the first three years the show paid homage to Lutteroth himself, from 1999 through 2004 the show paid homage to Lutteroth and [[El Santo]], Mexico's most famous wrestler ever<ref name=MondoSanto>{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha Libre: the bizarre & honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=Okay... what is Lucha Libre?|pages=29–40|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}}</ref> and from 2005 forward the show has paid homage to Lutteroth and a different ''leyenda'' ("Legend") each year, celebrating the career and accomplishments of past CMLL stars. Originally billed as Homenaje a Salvador Lutteroth, it has been held under the Homenaje a Dos Leyendas ("Homage to two legends") since 1999 and is the only show outside of [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre Anniversary Shows|CMLL's Anniversary shows]] that CMLL has presented every year since its inception. All Homenaje a Dos Leyendas shows have been held in [[Arena México]] in [[Mexico City, Mexico]] which is CMLL's main venue, its "home".<ref name=Mondo>{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha A Go-Go: the bizarre & honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=El nacimient de un sueño (the birth of a dream)|pages=41–50|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}}</ref> Traditionally CMLL holds their major events on Friday Nights, which means the Homenaje a Dos Leyendas shows replace their regularly scheduled [[CMLL Super Viernes|Super Viernes]] show.<ref name=Mondo/> The 2017 show was the 23rd overall Homenaje a Dos Leyendas show produced by CMLL.
===Storylines=== The event featured six [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing [[Screenplay|scripted]] feuds, [[plot (narrative)|plots]] and [[narrative thread|storylines]]. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches.
===Homage to Salvador Lutteroth and Villano III=== {{main|Salvador Lutteroth|Villano III}} In September 1933 [[Salvador Lutteroth González]] founded [[Empresa Mexicana de Lucha Libre]] (EMLL), which would later be renamed Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre. Over time Lutteroth would become responsible for building both [[Arena Coliseo]] in Mexico City and [[Arena Mexico]], which became known as "The Cathedral of Lucha Libre".<ref name=Lutteroth>{{cite book|title=Lucha Libre: Masked Superstars of Mexican Wrestling|publisher=Distributed Art Publishers, Inc.|year=2005|chapter=Los Lutteroth / the Lutteroths|pages=20–27|isbn=968-6842-48-9}}</ref><ref name=MondoStart>{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha A Go-Go: the bizarre & honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=El nacimient de un sueño (the birth of a dream)|pages=41–50|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}}</ref> Over time EMLL became the oldest wrestling promotion in the world, with 2018 marking the 85th year of its existence.<ref name=WON>{{cite web | url=https://www.f4wonline.com/mexico/cmll-85th-aniversario-live-results-hair-vs-hair-tag-team-main-event-265781 | title=CMLL 85. Aniversario live results: hair vs. hair tag team main event | work=[[Wrestling Observer|Wrestling Observer Figure Four Online]] | date=September 14, 2018 | accessdate=September 15, 2018 | first=Chris | last=Aiken}}</ref> Lutteroth has often been credited with being the "father of Lucha Libre" introducing the concept of [[wrestling mask|masked wrestlers]] to Mexico as well as the ''Luchas de Apuestas'' match. Lutteroth died on September 5, 1987.<ref name=Lutteroth/> EMLL, late CMLL, remained under the ownership and control of the Lutteroth family as first Salvador's son Chavo Lutteroth and later his grandson [[Paco Alonso]] took over ownership of the company.<ref name="wonhof">{{cite book | last = Meltzer | first = Dave | title = Wrestling Observer Newsletter - September 8th 2008 | date= September 8, 2008}}</ref>
The life and achievements of Salvador Lutteroth is always honored at the annual Homenaje a Dos Leyendas show, since 1999 CMLL has also honored a second person, a ''Leyenda'' of lucha libre, in some ways CMLL's version of their [[Hall of Fame]]. In 2017 CMLL chose to honor Arturo Díaz Mendoza, best known under the [[ring name]] [[Villano III]] ("Villain 3") for his life and career in Lucha Libre. Arturo Mendoza was the middle son of wrestler/promoter [[Ray Mendoza]], following José de Jesús Díaz Mendoza (aka. [[Villano I]]) and José Alfredo Díaz Mendoz ([[Villano II]]) and younger brothers Raymundo Díaz Mendoza Jr. ([[Villano V]]) and Tomas Díaz Mendoza ([[Villano V]]). His career really took off when Ray Mendoza, [[Francisco Flores (wrestling)|Francisco Flores]] and Benjamin Mora Jr. broke away from CMLL to form the [[Universal Wrestling Association]] (UWA) where Arturo became one of the stars of their lighter weight divisions holding the [[UWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship]],<ref name=UWAJunior>{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|chapter=Mexico: Universal Wrestling Federation Light Heavyweight Title|page=397|year=2000|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref> the [[UWA World Junior Light Heavyweight Championship]],<ref name=UWAJrLight>{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications |chapter=Mexico: Universal Wrestling Federation Junior Light Heavyweight Title|page=397|year=2000|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref> the [[UWA World Light Heavyweight Championship]] twice,<ref name=UWALHeavy>{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|chapter=Mexico: UWA Lightweight Title|page=400|year=2000|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref> the [[UWA World Welterweight Championship]]<ref name=UWAWelter>{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|chapter=Mexico: Universal Wrestling Federation Welterweight Heavyweight Title|page=397|year=2000|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref> and the [[WWF Light Heavyweight Championship]] 7 times.<ref name=WWFLHeavy>{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|year=2006|edition=4th|chapter=Mexico: UWA WWF World Light Heavyweight Title|page=399|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref><ref group=Note>Though Villano III won the title seven times, none of the reigns are officially recognized by the [[WWE]]. No reign prior to December 1997 is officially recognized by the WWE.</ref> Over the years Villano III defended his mask in a multitude of ''[[Luchas de Apuestas]]'' matches, with more than 30 mask wins on his record, including unmasking Super Astro and [[Chris Benoit|Pegasus Kid]].<ref name=V3Apuestas>{{Cite news|title=Luchas 2000|work=Villano III y sus Victimas|publisher=Publicaciones citem, S.A. de C.V.|location=[[Ciudad Juárez|Juárez]], Mexico|id=Especial 30|pages=24–27|language=Spanish}}</ref> In late-1999/early-2000 Villano III started a storyline feud with [[Atlantis (wrestler)|Atlantis]] that led to both wrestlers putting their mask on the line at the 2000 [[Juicio Final (2000)|Juicio Final]]. Villano III lost the match and his mask in what was voted as the [[Wrestling Observer]] [[Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Match of the Year|Match of the Year]] for 2001. In subsequent years Arturo's career slowed down as age and injuries took a toll on him. He finally retired in 2015 due to diminishing eyesight and deteriorating knees.<ref name=Retirement>{{cite web | url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/mas-deportes/lucha-libre/noticias/2015/05/21/el-villano-iii-anuncio-su-retiro | title=El Villano III anunció su retiro | date=May 21, 2015 | accessdate=May 23, 2015 | work=MedioTiempo | publisher=[[MSN]] | language=Spanish}}</ref>

{{flagicon image|Flag of the MRTA.svg}} [[Néstor Cerpa Cartolini]] | strength1 = | strength2 = 15,000 (peak)
~250–650 (2015){{cite web|url=http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=39249|title=Hot Issue — On The Rebound: Shining Path Factions Vie for Control of Upper Huallaga Valley|work=The Jamestown Foundation|accessdate=October 18, 2014}}{{cite web |url=https://wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/09LIMA543_a.html|title=SHINING PATH IN THE VRAE|date=13 April 2009|accessdate=18 October 2014}} | casualties1 = 69,280 killed by the conflict (until 2002){{cite web|title=Final Report|url=http://www.cverdad.org.pe/ingles/pagina01.php|work=Press Release|publisher=Truth and reconciliation commission|accessdate=}} | casualties2 = | campaign = | casus = Decision by [[guerrilla warfare|guerrillas]] to rise against Peruvian state }} {{Peru conflict}} The '''internal conflict in Peru''' is an ongoing [[armed conflict]] between the [[Government of Peru]], [[Shining Path|the Communist Party of Peru]] (better known as ''Shining Path'' or "PCP-SL"), and the [[Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement]]. The conflict began on May 17, 1980. Estimates indicate that there have been nearly 70,000 deaths, making it the bloodiest war in [[History of Peru|Peruvian history]] since the [[European colonization of the Americas|European colonization of the country]]. The high death toll includes many civilian casualties resulting from deliberate targeting by many factions. Recently, however, the conflict has become dormant as the number of deaths dropped significantly since the year 2000. There were low-level resurgences of violence in 2002 and 2014 when conflict erupted between the Peruvian Army and guerrilla remnants in the VRAEM region. The conflict has lasted for over 38 years, making it the second longest internal conflict in the [[history of Latin America]], after the [[Colombian armed conflict]]. ==Background== Prior to the conflict, Peru had undergone a series of coups with frequent switches between different parties and ideologies. On October 2, 1968,{{Cite journal|last=Brands|first=Hal|date=2010-09-14|title=The United States and the Peruvian Challenge, 1968–1975|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/09592296.2010.508418|journal=Diplomacy & Statecraft|language=en|volume=21|issue=3|pages=471–490|doi=10.1080/09592296.2010.508418|issn=0959-2296}} General [[Juan Velasco Alvarado]] staged a [[military coup]] and became Peru's 56th president under the administration of the Revolutionary Government of the Armed Forces, a left-leaning military dictatorship.{{cn|date=November 2018}} Following a period of widespread poverty and unemployment, Velasco himself was overthrown by a bloodless [[Tacnazo|military coup]] on August 29, 1975, and was replaced by [[Francisco Morales Bermúdez]] as the new [[President of Peru]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1975/08/30/archives/president-of-peru-ousted-in-coup-led-by-the-military-peruvian.html|title=President of Peru Ousted In Coup Led by the Military|last=Hofmann|first=Paul|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en}} Morales made an announcement that his rule would provide a "Second Phase" to the previous administration which would bring great political and economic reform to the country.{{Cite web|url=http://biography.yourdictionary.com/francisco-morales-bermudez-cerruti|title=Francisco Morales-Bermúdez Cerruti Facts|website=biography.yourdictionary.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-12}} However, he was unsuccessful in delivering on his promises and in 1978 a Constitutional Assembly was created to replace Peru's 1933 Constitution. Morales then proclaimed that national elections would be held by 1980.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1977/07/29/archives/perus-military-regime-pledges-civilian-rule-in-1980.html|title=Peru's Military Regime Pledges Civilian Rule in 1980|last=Onis|first=Juan de|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en}} Elections were held for the Constituent Assembly on June 18, 1978, martial law was imposed on January 6, 1979, and the Assembly approved the new constitution in July 1979. On May 18, 1980 Fernando Belaunda Terry was elected president. During the years between February 1966 and July 1980 about 500 people died in political violence.{{Cite web|url=http://uca.edu/politicalscience/dadm-project/western-hemisphere-region/peru-1912-present/|title=13. Peru (1912-present)|website=uca.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-12}} Many affiliated with Peru's Communist Party had opposed the creation of the new constitution and formed the extremist organization known as the "Shining Path". This ultimately led to the beginning of Peru's internal conflict, with the first attacks taking place only a day before the elections. Despite this, national elections continued and [[Fernando Belaúnde Terry]] was elected as the 58th President of Peru in 1980. Terry had already served as the country's 55th president prior to Velasco's coup in 1968.{{cn|date=November 2018}} ==Rise of Shining Path== During the governments of Velasco and Morales, [[Shining Path]] had been organized as a [[Maoism|Maoist]] political group based at the [[San Cristóbal of Huamanga University]] in the [[Ayacucho Region]]. It was founded in 1970, and led by [[Abimael Guzmán]], a communist professor of philosophy at the San Cristóbal of Huamanga University. Guzmán had been inspired by the [[Cultural Revolution]], which he had witnessed first-hand during a trip to China.{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Shining-Path|title=Shining Path {{!}} Peruvian revolutionary organization|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en}} Shining Path members engaged in street fights with members of other political groups and painted [[graffiti]] exhorting "armed struggle" against the Peruvian state.{{Cite web|url=https://www.georgiastandards.org/resources/Lexile_in_Action/SSWH20_1040.pdf|title=Abimael Guzman and the Shining Path|last=Streissguth|first=Thomas|date=5 November 2009|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 November 2018}} ==Outbreak of hostilities== When Peru's [[Military dictatorship|military government]] allowed [[Elections in Peru|elections]] for the first time in a dozen years in 1980, Shining Path was one of the few [[leftist]] political groups that declined to take part, instead opting to launch [[guerrilla warfare]] actions against the state in the highlands of the province of [[Ayacucho Region|Ayacucho]]. On May 17, 1980, the eve of [[Peruvian general election, 1980|the presidential elections]], they burned ballot boxes in the town of [[Chuschi|Chuschi,]] Ayacucho. It was the first "act of terrorism" by Shining Path. Nonetheless, the perpetrators were quickly caught and additional ballots were brought in to replace the burned ballots; the elections proceeded without any further incidents with the act receiving very little attention in the Peruvian press.''The Shining Path: A History of the Millenarian War in Peru.'' p. 17. Gorriti, Gustavo trans. Robin Kirk, The University of North Carolina Press: Chapel Hill and London, 1999 ({{ISBN|0-8078-4676-7}}). Shining Path opted to fight in the style taught by [[Mao Zedong]]. They would open up "guerrilla zones" in which their guerrillas could operate and drive government forces out of these zones to create "liberated zones." These zones would then be used to support new guerrilla zones until the entire country was essentially one big "liberated zone." Shining Path also adhered to Mao's teaching that guerrilla should be fought primarily in the countryside and gradually choke off the cities.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} On December 3, 1982, the Shining Path officially formed a "People's Guerrilla Army", its armed wing.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} ==Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement== {{main|Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement}} [[File:Flag of the MRTA.svg|thumb|left|The flag of the MRTA|180px]] In 1982, the [[Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement]] (MRTA) launched its own guerrilla against the Peruvian state. The group had been formed by remnants of the [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Peru)|Movement of the Revolutionary Left]] in Peru and identified with [[Politics of Fidel Castro|Castroite]] guerrilla movements in other parts of Latin America. The MRTA used techniques that were more traditional to Latin American [[leftist]] organizations than those used by Shining Path. For example, the MRTA wore uniforms, claimed to be fighting for true democracy and complained of human rights abuses by the state, while Shining Path did not wear uniforms and had little regard for the democratic process and human rights.La Comisión de la Verdad y Reconciliación. ''Final Report.'' "General Conclusions." [http://www.cverdad.org.pe/ingles/ifinal/conclusiones.php Available online]. Accessed February 3, 2007.{{Additional citation needed|date=August 2018}} During the conflict, the MRTA and Shining Path engaged in combat with each other. The MRTA played a small part in the overall conflict, being declared by the [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (Peru)|Truth and Reconciliation Commission]] to have been responsible for 1.5% of deaths accumulated throughout the conflict. At its height, the MRTA was believed to have consisted of only a few hundred members. ==Government response== Gradually, the Shining Path committed more and more violent attacks on the [[National Police of Peru]] and the Lima-based government could no longer ignore the growing crisis in the [[Andes]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} In 1981, [[Fernando Belaúnde Terry]] declared a [[State of Emergency]] and ordered that the [[Peruvian Armed Forces]] fight the Shining Path.{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} Constitutional rights were suspended for 60 days in [[Huamanga Province]], [[Huanta Province]], [[Cangallo Province]], [[La Mar Province]] and [[Víctor Fajardo Province]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} Later, the Armed Forces created the Ayacucho Emergency Zone, in which military power was superior to civilian power, and many constitutional rights were suspended.{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} The military committed many human rights violations in the area where it had political control, including the infamous [[Accomarca massacre]]. Scores of peasants were massacred by the armed forces.''[[BBC News]]''. "Peruvians seek relatives in mass grave." June 12, 2008. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7449079.stm Available online]. Retrieved June 12, 2008. A special US-trained "[[counterterrorist|counter terrorist]]" police battalion known as the "Sinchis" were particularly notorious in the '80s for their human rights violations.Palmer, David Scott (2007). The revolutionary terrorism of Peru's Shining Path. In Martha Crenshaw, Ed. Terrorism in Context. University Park, PA: Pennsylvania State University Press. ==Escalation of the conflict== {{History of Peru}} The reaction of the Shining Path to the Peruvian government's use of the military in the conflict was not to back down, but instead to ramp up the level of violence in the countryside. Shining Path attacked police officers, soldiers, and civilians that it considered to be "class enemies", often using particularly gruesome methods{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} of killing their victims. These killings, along with Shining Path's disrespect for the culture of indigenous peasants{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} it claimed to represent, turned many people in the sierra away from the group. Faced with a hostile population, the Shining Path's guerrilla began to falter. In some areas, some fearful, well-off peasants formed anti-Shining Path patrols, called ''rondas''. They were generally poorly equipped, despite donations of guns from the armed forces. Nevertheless, Shining Path guerrillas were militarily attacked by the ''rondas''. The first such reported attack was in January 1983 near [[Huata]], where some ''rondas'' killed 13 guerrillas; in February in Sacsamarca, ''rondas'' stabbed and killed the Shining Path commanders of that area. In March 1983, ''rondas'' brutally killed Olegario Curitomay, one of the commanders of the town of [[Lucanamarca]]. They took him to the town square, stoned him, stabbed him, set him on fire and finally, shot him.La Comisión de la Verdad y Reconciliación. "La Masacre de Lucanamarca (1983)." August 28, 2003. [http://www.cverdad.org.pe/ifinal/pdf/TOMO%20VII/Casos%20Ilustrativos-UIE/2.6.%20LUCANAMARCA.pdf Available online in Spanish] Accessed February 1, 2006. As a response, in April, Shining Path entered the province of [[Huancasancos]] and the towns of Yanaccollpa, Ataccara, Llacchua, Muylacruz, and Lucanamarca and [[Lucanamarca massacre|killed 69 people]], many of whom were children, including one who was only six months old. Also killed were several women, some of them pregnant. Most of them died by machete hacks and some were shot at close range in the head. This was the first massacre committed by Shining Path against the peasant community. Other incidents followed, such as the one in [[Hauyllo]], [[Tambo District, La Mar|Tambo District]], [[La Mar Province]]and Ayacucho Department. In that community, Shining Path killed 47 peasants, including 14 children aged four to fifteen.Amnesty International. "Peru: Human rights in a time of impunity." February 2006. [http://web.amnesty.org/library/index/ENGAMR460011996 Available online] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021151357/http://web.amnesty.org/library/index/ENGAMR460011996 |date=October 21, 2006 }}. Retrieved September 24, 2006. Additional massacres by Shining Path occurred, such as one in [[Marcas District|Marcas]] on August 29, 1985.La Comisión de la Verdad y Reconciliación. "Ataque del PCP-SL a la Localidad de Marcas (1985)." [http://www.cverdad.org.pe/ifinal/pdf/TOMO%20VII/Casos%20Ilustrativos-UIE/2.18.%20MARCAS.pdf Available online in Spanish] Accessed February 1, 2006.La Comisión de la Verdad y Reconciliación. "Press Release 170." [http://www.cverdad.org.pe/ingles/informacion/nprensa/notas.php?idnota=117 Available online] Accessed February 1, 2006. The Shining Path, like the government, filled its ranks by [[conscription]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} The Shining Path also kidnapped children and forced them to fight as child soldiers in their actions.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} ==Administration of Alberto Fujimori (1990–2000) and decline== Under the administration of [[Alberto Fujimori]] the state started its widespread use of intelligence agencies in its fight against Shining Path. Some atrocities were allegedly committed by the [[National Intelligence Service (Peru)|National Intelligence Service]], notably the [[La Cantuta massacre]], the [[Barrios Altos massacre]] and the [[Santa massacre]]. On April 5, 1992, Fujimori dissolved the [[Congress of Peru]] and abolished the Constitution, initiating the [[Peruvian Constitutional Crisis of 1992]]. The reason for these actions was that the Congress was slow to pass anti-terrorism legislation. Fujimori set up military courts to try suspected members of the Shining Path and MRTA, and ordered that an "iron fist" approach be used. Fujimori also announced that Peru would no longer be under the jurisdiction of the [[Inter-American Court of Human Rights]]. As Shining Path began to lose ground in the Andes to the Peruvian state and the rondas, it decided to speed up its overall strategic plan. Shining Path declared that it had reached "strategic equilibrium" and was ready to begin its final assault on the cities of Peru. In 1992, Shining Path set off a powerful bomb in the [[Miraflores District, Lima|Miraflores District]] of [[Lima]] in what became known as the [[Tarata bombing]]. This was part of a larger bombing campaign to follow suit in Lima. On September 12, 1992, Peruvian police captured Guzmán and several Shining Path leaders in an apartment above a dance studio in the [[Surquillo]] district of Lima. The police had been monitoring the apartment, as a number of suspected Shining Path militants had visited it. An inspection of the garbage of the apartment produced empty tubes of a skin cream used to treat [[psoriasis]], a condition that Guzmán was known to have. Shortly after the raid that captured Guzmán, most of the remaining Shining Path leadership fell as well.Rochlin, James F. ''Vanguard Revolutionaries in Latin America: Peru, Colombia, Mexico.'' p. 71. Lynne Rienner Publishers: Boulder and London, 2003. ({{ISBN|1-58826-106-9}}). At the same time, Shining Path suffered embarrassing military defeats to peasant self-defense organizations – supposedly its social base – and the organization fractured into splinter groups.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} Guzmán's role as the leader of Shining Path was taken over by [[Óscar Ramírez]], who himself was captured by Peruvian authorities in 1999. After Ramírez's capture, the group splintered, guerrilla activity diminished sharply and previous conditions returned to the areas where the Shining Path had been active.Rochlin, James F. ''Vanguard Revolutionaries in Latin America: Peru, Colombia, Mexico.'' pp. 71–72. [[Lynne Rienner Publishers]]: Boulder and London, 2003. ({{ISBN|1-58826-106-9}}). Some Shining Path and MRTA remnants managed to stage minor scale attacks, such as the January 1993 wave of attacks and political assassinations that occurred in the run-up to the municipal elections, which also targeted US interests; these included the bombing of two [[Coca-Cola]] plants on January 22 (by Shining Path); the [[Rocket-propelled grenade|RPG]] attack against the [[United States Information Agency|USIS]] Binational Center on January 16; the bombing of a [[KFC]] restaurant on January 21 (both by the MRTA) and the car-bombing of the Peruvian headquarters of [[IBM]] on January 28 (by Shining Path).https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/19813.pdf{{rp|2-3}} On July 27, 1993, Shining Path militants drove a car bomb into the US Embassy in Lima, which left extensive damage on the complex (worth some USD$250.000) and nearby buildings.{{rp|7-9}} Shining Path confined to their former headquarters in the Peruvian jungle and continued smaller attacks against the military, like the one that occurred on October 2, 1999, when a [[Peruvian Army]] helicopter was shot down by SP guerrillas near [[Satipo (town)|Satipo]] (killing 5) and stealing a [[PK machine gun|PKM]] machine gun which was reportedly used in another attack against an [[Mil Mi-17|Mi-17]] in July 2003.{{cite web|url=http://agenciaperu.com/investigacion/2003/jul/helicoptero.htm |title=INVESTIGACIÓN | Sendero atacó helicóptero en el que viajaba general EP |publisher=agenciaperu.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-15}} Despite Shining Path being mostly defeated, more that 25% of Peru's national territory remained under a [[state of emergency]] until early 2000.{{cite book|title=[[Financial Times]] World Desk Reference|last1=Heritage|first1=Andrew|date=December 2002|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]]|year=|isbn=9780789488053|location=|pages=462-465}} ==Truth and Reconciliation Commission== Alberto Fujimori resigned the Presidency in 2000, but Congress declared him "morally unfit", installing the opposite congress member [[Valentín Paniagua]] into office. He rescinded Fujimori's announcement that Peru would leave the Inter-American Court of Human Rights and established a [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (Peru)|Truth and Reconciliation Commission]] (CVR) to investigate the conflict. The commission was headed by the President of [[Catholic University]] [[Salomón Lerner Febres]]. The Commission found in its 2003 ''Final Report'' that 69,280 people died or [[Forced disappearance|disappeared]] between 1980 and 2000 as a result of the armed conflict.Comisión de la Verdad y Reconciliación. [http://www.cverdad.org.pe/ifinal/pdf/Tomo%20-%20ANEXOS/ANEXO%202.pdf Annex 2] Page 17. Retrieved January 14, 2008. A statistical analysis of the available data led the Truth and Reconciliation Commission to estimate that the Shining Path was responsible for the death or disappearance of 31,331 people, 45% of the total deaths and disappearances. According to a summary of the report by [[Human Rights Watch]], "Shining Path... killed about half the victims, and roughly one-third died at the hands of government security forces... The commission attributed some of the other slayings to a smaller guerrilla group and local militias. The rest remain unattributed."Human Rights Watch. August 28, 2003. [http://hrw.org/english/docs/2003/08/28/peru6334.htm "Peru – Prosecutions Should Follow Truth Commission Report"]. Retrieved January 13, 2008. According to its final report, 75% of the people who were either killed or [[Forced disappearance|disappeared]] spoke [[Quechua languages|Quechua]] as their native language, despite the fact that the 1993 census found that only 20% of Peruvians speak Quechua or another indigenous language as their native language.{{cite web|title=CVR. Tomo VIII. Chapter 2. "El impacto diferenciado de la violencia" "2.1 VIOLENCIA Y DESIGUALDAD RACIAL Y ÉTNICA" |pages=131–132|url=http://www.cverdad.org.pe/ifinal/pdf/TOMO%20VIII/SEGUNDA%20PARTE/Impacto%20diferenciado%20de%20la%20violencia/2.2.%20DISCRIMINACION%20ETNICA.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=18 October 2014}} Nevertheless, the final report of the CVR was surrounded by controversy. {{USA}} (Accused) |side2='''Left-wing'''

'''Supported by:'''
{{flag|Cuba}} (Accused)
{{flag|Soviet Union|1955}} (Accused) |commander1= |commander2= |strength1= |strength2= |casualties1= |casualties2= |campaign= |casus= }} {{Campaignbox Jamaican political conflict}} The '''Jamaican political conflict''' is a long standing feud between right-wing and left-wing elements in the country, often exploding into violence. The [[Jamaican Labor Party]] and the [[People's National Party]] have fought for control of the island for years and the rivalry has encouraged urban warfare in [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]]. Each side believes the other to be controlled by foreign elements, the JLP is said to be backed by the American [[Central Intelligence Agency]] and the PNP is said to been backed by the [[Soviet Union]] and [[Fidel Castro]].{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1980/09/05/jamaicas-political-war/e62395de-1e45-4a88-b4d2-7e90e26a1fca/?utm_term=.06d2e65b8796 |title=Jamaica's Political War |date=September 5, 1994|publisher=[[Washington Post]] }} ==History== ===Beginning=== By 1943 the JLP and PNP had established themselves as Jamaica's main rival political parties coming out of the recent [[British West Indian labour unrest of 1934–39|Caribbean labor unrest]]. After the [[Jamaican general election, 1944|election of 1944]] violence became a common aspect of their rivalry. [[Alexander Bustamante]] began to encourage the attack of PNP sympathizers, claiming they were communists.{{cite web|url=https://academiccommons.columbia.edu/catalog/ac:157025 |title=The Evolution of Political Violence in Jamaica 1940-1980 |last=Williams |first=Karen |publisher=[[Columbia University]] }} ===Escalation=== Political violence had become commonplace in Jamaica. Political parties began paying off crime bosses for local gang support. Assassination threats and attempts also starting becoming more frequent.{{cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/columns/Assassination-plots-and-the-birth-of-political-violence-in-Jamaica_18348840 |title=Assassination plots and the birth of political violence in Jamaica |publisher=Jamaica Observer }} Sporadic political violence would evolve into outright urban warfare after a series of violent outbursts. The [[Henry rebellion]], the [[Coral Gardens uprising]], the [[anti-Chinese riots of 1965]], the state of emergency of 1966-67, and finally the [[Rodney riots]]. These events sparked an emerging ethnic nationalist element to the political conflict and increased partisan warfare.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QjvpAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA82&lpg=PA82&dq=rasta+rebellion+1960&source=bl&ots=HwZahJkr0W&sig=eKg9yM0Om-zcQYxuWJxp7_wpShs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjonJ7WyqbcAhXD21MKHZgcCtsQ6AEwEXoECAMQAQ#v=onepage&q=rasta%20rebellion%201960&f=false |title=Violence and Politics in Jamaica, 1960-70: Internal Security in a Developing Country |last=Lacey |first=Terry |publisher=Jamaica Observer }} By the 1976 election over a hundred had been murdered during the conflict and political parties began forming paramilitary divisions.{{cite web|url=https://history.libraries.wsu.edu/spring2017/2017/01/20/political-violence-in-jamaica |title=Political Violence in Jamaica |last=Fisher |first=Trey|publisher=Washington State University }} In 1978 five [[Green Bay massacre|JLP supporters were massacred]] by official Jamaican soldiers.{{cite book|last1=Gunst|first1=Laurie|title=Born Fi' Dead|publisher=Canongate Books Ltd|isbn=978-1841953861|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=noe6wTVKdfkC&pg=PT99&lpg=PT99&dq=%22green+bay%22+%22Major+Ian+Robinson%22&source=bl&ots=b8AvqXGFgQ&sig=_HBN_PlsJZQXPdOtiEvZLuxHM70&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj57fPLiMLWAhXKa7wKHbXWA8gQ6AEIOjAD#v=onepage&q=%22green%20bay%22%20%22Major%20Ian%20Robinson%22&f=false|accessdate=26 September 2017}} [[Reggae]] music became a voice for peace in the country and the landmark [[One Love Peace Concert]] was held in hopes of peace. By the 1980 election 844 people were murdered in political violence preceding the vote.{{cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/The-bloody-general-election-that-changed-Jamaica |title=The bloody general election that changed Jamaica |publisher=Jamaica Observer }} ===Recent developments=== Despite many peace accords it is still common for political parties to pay off criminals for support and encourage paramilitary garrisons.{{cite web|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20100321/focus/focus3.html |title=Evolution Of Garrison Politics |publisher=Jamaica Gleamer }} ==See also== * [[Colombian conflict]] * [[Dirty War (Mexico)|Mexican Dirty War]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Cold War}} [[Category:Civil wars post-1945|Jamaica]] [[Category:Cold War conflicts]] [[Category:Communism-based civil wars|Jamaica]] [[Category:Cuba–United States relations]] [[Category:Guerrilla wars|Jamaica]] [[Category:Ongoing conflicts|Jamaica]] [[Category:Proxy wars]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Jamaica]] [[Category:Terrorism in Jamaica]] [[Category:United States–Caribbean relations]]
