[[File:Super Bowl trophy (3785852933).jpg|thumb|223px|The [[National Football League|NFL's]] [[Super Bowl]] championship trophy, the [[Vince Lombardi Trophy]], was named in honor of [[Vince Lombardi]] after his death in 1970.]]
'''The Lombardi Curse''' was an alleged [[sports-related curses|sports-related curse]] that supposedly prevented the [[National Football League]] (NFL)'s [[Philadelphia Eagles]] franchise from winning the [[Super Bowl]] for as long as the game's [[Vince Lombardi Trophy|trophy]] is named after [[Vince Lombardi]].{{fact|date=February 2018}} Its origin is traced to the Eagles upsetting the [[Green Bay Packers]] in the [[1960 NFL Championship Game]]. This game ended up being the lone playoff defeat in Lombardi's coaching career as his Packers would go on to establish a dynasty that would win five NFL championships in the next seven seasons, including the [[Super Bowl I|first]] [[Super Bowl II|two]] Super Bowls.
Meanwhile, the Eagles had not won another league championship since, including having never won the Super Bowl since the game started being played annually in 1966. They appeared in [[Super Bowl XV]] in the 1980 season and [[Super Bowl XXXIX]] in the 2004 season, but lost both times. In 1970, the Super Bowl trophy was officially named the Vince Lombardi trophy when the league decided to honor Lombardi by naming the trophy after him following his death in 1970.<ref>{{cite news|last=Weatherly|first=Kaleel|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2017/2/5/14515842/vince-lombardi-trophy-nfl-championship-super-bowl|title=Why is the Lombardi Trophy named after Vince Lombardi?|website=[[SB Nation]]|date=February 5, 2017|accessdate=September 17, 2017}}</ref> This renaming of the Super Bowl trophy combined with the Eagles inability to win the championship game has led some Eagles fans to believe that the franchise is cursed by Vince Lombardi; that beating Lombardi meant never winning the trophy named after him.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wDkpDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT14&lpg=PT14&dq=eagles+lombardi+curse&source=bl&ots=3jd2qN3Dlx&sig=Ta6DzH1Ia7nv6QgicJpnjq0ILvY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwifw_XZ6ZPVAhUCND4KHYKACjAQ6AEIVTAJ#v=onepage&q=eagles+lombardi+curse&f=false|title=Big 50: Philadelphia Eagles: The Men and Moments that Made the Philadelphia Eagles|first=Mark|last=Eckel|date=15 September 2016|publisher=Triumph Books|via=Google Books}}</ref>
The Eagles defeated the [[New England Patriots]] by a score of 41 to 33 in [[Super Bowl LII]] at [[U.S. Bank Stadium]] in [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] on February 4, 2018, ending the alleged curse.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wesseling|first=Chris|title=Philadelphia Eagles knock off Patriots, win Super Bowl|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000914459/article/philadelphia-eagles-knock-off-patriots-win-super-bowl|publisher=National Football League|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 5, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Cormier|first=Ryan|title=Three generations of Delaware family kiss Lombardi Trophy|url=https://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/2018/02/05/three-generations-delaware-family-kiss-lombardi-trophy/306533002/|publisher=The News Journal|date=February 5, 2018|accessdate=February 10, 2018}}</ref>
==Origins== In 1958, the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] offered and nearly hired [[Vince Lombardi]] to be their head coach after having served as the offensive coordinator for the [[New York Giants]], but after some discussion he refused it in the end.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fitzpatrick|first=Frank|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/eagles/20150131_How_Lombardi_almost_became_Eagles_coach.html|title=How Lombardi almost became Eagles coach|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=January 31, 2015|accessdate=September 17, 2017}}</ref> The Eagles were reportedly not happy with his decision.<ref name="wordpress.com">{{cite web|url=https://brokenbellsports.wordpress.com/category/are-the-philadelphia-eagles-cursed-by-vince-lombardi/|title=Are the Philadelphia Eagles Cursed by Vince Lombardi? – BrokenBellSports|website=brokenbellsports.wordpress.com}}</ref>
The Eagles hired [[Buck Shaw]] as their head coach later that offseason. After spending an additional season with the Giants, Lombardi would go on to become head coach for the [[Green Bay Packers]] in 1959.
On December 26, 1960, the Eagles defeated Lombardi and the Packers 17–13 in the [[1960 NFL Championship Game]]. While the Eagles organization celebrated the victory over the man who had turned them down two years earlier, Lombardi did not take the loss kindly, and it is said that the loss is what drove him for the rest of his coaching career.<ref name="wordpress.com"/> He took the blame for the loss and reportedly told his team after the game that "We'll never lose another championship".<ref>{{cite news|last=Longman|first=Jeré|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/07/sports/football/07eagles.html|title=Eagles’ 1960 Victory Was an N.F.L. Turning Point|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 7, 2011|accessdate=September 17, 2017}}</ref> Lombardi would fulfill his promise, as the Packers went 9–0 with Lombardi in the playoffs since that defeat, winning five championships which included the first two Super Bowls.
Meanwhile, the Eagles did not win another championship for 57 years, the [[List of NFL franchise post-season droughts#Super Bowl win droughts|third longest]] active title drought among all NFL franchises after the [[Arizona Cardinals]] and [[Detroit Lions]]. In 1970, Lombardi passed away following a battle with cancer, and the league decided to honor him by naming the Super Bowl trophy after him. While there are no reports that Lombardi has said anything that would suggest he placed a curse on the Eagles, some{{whom|date=August 2017}} Eagles fans believed the franchise was cursed to never win the Super Bowl for as long as the game's trophy was named after the man they handed his lone playoff defeat to.

Théâtre des Arts (1907-1940) | production = | currentuse = | website = www.theatrehebertot.com }} '''Théâtre Hébertot''' {{IPA-fr|te.ɑtʁ e.bɛʁ.to|}} is a theatre at 78, boulevard des Batignolles, in the [[17th arrondissement of Paris]], France. The theatre, completed in 1838 and opening as the '''Théâtre des Batignolles''', was later renamed '''Théâtre des Arts''' in 1907. It acquired its present name in 1940 after [[playwright]] and journalist [[Jacques Hébertot]]. Théâtre Hébertot has a seating capacity of 630 for the main stage, and completed construction on a smaller stage, l'Petit Hébertot, in 2001. The Hebertot is one of the few Paris theaters that has shows in English as well as French. {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Triplemanía V-B |image=TriplemaniaV.jpg |caption=Logo of Triplemanía V from the television broadcast |promotion=[[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]] |date=June 15, 1997{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#v-b | title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = 2009-02-19| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}} |attendance= |venue=El Toreo |city=[[Naucalpan]], Mexico |lastevent=[[Triplemanía V-A]] |nextevent = [[Verano de Escándalo (1997)]] |event=[[Triplemanía]] |lastevent2=[[Triplemanía V-A]] |nextevent2=[[Triplemanía VI]] }} '''Triplemanía V-B''' was the second part of the fifth [[Triplemanía]] [[professional wrestling]] show promoted by [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]]. 1997 was fourth year to feature the "Triplemanía Series" of shows with two, referred to as V-A and V-B, where this was the second and final of the series. The show took place on June 15, 1997 in Naulcalpan, Mexico. The main event featured an [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Trios rules (Relevos Australianos)|eight-man "Atómicos" tag-team match]] between the teams of [[Perro Aguayo]], [[Octagón]], [[Cibernético]] and [[El Canek]] and [[Jake Roberts]], [[Gorgeous George III]], El Cobarde Jr. and [[Fuerza Guerrera]]. ==Production== ===Background=== In early 1992 [[Antonio Peña]] was working as a booker and storyline writer for [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL), Mexico's largest and the world's oldest wrestling promotion, and was frustrated by CMLL's very conservative approach to ''[[lucha libre]]''. He joined forced with a number of younger, very talented wrestlers who felt like CMLL was not giving them the recognition they deserved and decided to split from CMLL to create [[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]], later known simply as "AAA" or Triple A. After making a deal with the ''Televisa'' television network AAA held their first show in April 1992.{{cite web | url= http://superluchas.net/2006/10/07/el-fin-de-una-era/| title= El fin de una era| date= October 7, 2006 | accessdate= October 14, 2009 | author= Ocampo, Ernesto | publisher= ''SuperLuchas'' Magazine | language=Spanish}} The following year Peña and AAA held their first [[Triplemanía]] event, building it into an annual event that would become AAA's [[Super Bowl]] event, similar to the [[WWE]]'s [[WrestleMania]] being the biggest show of the year.{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha Libre: the bizarre and honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=A family affair|pages=128–132|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}} The 1997 Triplemanía was the fifth year in a row AAA held a Triplemanía show and the twelfth overall show under the Triplemanía banner. ===Storylines=== The Triplemanía V-B show featured eight [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing [[Screenplay|scripted]] feuds, [[plot (narrative)|plots]] and [[narrative thread|storylines]]. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches. ==Results== {{Pro Wrestling {{Infobox company |name = Unaoil |logo = |type = Private |foundation = 1991 |location_city = [[La Rousse]] |location_country = [[Monaco]] |location = |locations = |key_people = [[Ahsani family]] |area_served = |industry = [[Oil industry]] |products = |services = |operating_income = |revenue = |net_income = |num_employees = |parent = |subsid = |slogan = |homepage = |dissolved = |footnotes = |intl = }} '''Unaoil''' is a [[Monaco]] based company run by the [[Ahsani family]] founded in 1991.<ref name="UnaoilDotCom">{{cite web | url = http://unaoil.com |title=Heritage | website = Unaoil.com | access-date = 2016-03-30}}</ref> According to Unaoil, it provides "industrial solutions to the energy sector in the Middle East, Central Asia and Africa."<ref name="UnaoilDotComMsg">{{cite web | url = http://www.unaoil.com/about/chairman-s-message/ |title="CHAIRMAN'S MESSAGE" | website = Unaoil.com | access-date = 2016-03-31}}</ref><ref name="UnaoilDotCom" /> Unaoil is [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] in the [[British Virgin Islands]], a [[tax haven]] with an opaque banking system.<ref name=smh2013>{{cite news|url= http://www.smh.com.au/business/leighton-holdings-linked-to-corrupt-fees-for-iraq-pipeline-contracts-20131117-2xp8b.html |title= Leighton Holdings linked to 'corrupt' fees for Iraq pipeline contracts |work= [[The Australian]] |first1= Nick |last1= McKenzie |first2= Richard |last2= Baker |date= 2013-11-18 |accessdate= 2016-04-02}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
==Allegations of bribery== In 2010 Unaoil entered into an agreement with [[CIMIC Group|Leighton Holdings]] with the aim of securing a $500 million oil pipeline contract in Iraq. In 2011 Leighton Holdings referred the deal to the police as corruption.<ref name=smh2013/> In 2014 a UK High Court judge queried the corruption claims after Unaoil denied them in a civil litigation matter involving Leighton Holidngs.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/companies/leighton-corruption-evidence-at-best-tenuous-uk-judge-says/news-story/e3851477f3a2e7e00551c5d31b9f3ad5 |title= Leighton corruption evidence ‘at best tenuous’, UK judge says |work= The Australian |first= Damon |last= Kitney |date= 2015-03-10 |accessdate= 2016-04-01}}{{subscription required}}</ref> In 2016, the UK [[Serious Fraud Office (United Kingdom)|Serious Fraud Office]] alleged before the UK High Court in a separate case brought by Unaoil that the firm was engaged in "extensive" corruption.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2016/dec/01/monaco-oil-firm-starts-legal-action-against-serious-office|title=Monaco oil firm starts legal action against Serious Fraud Office|last=Evans|first=Rob|date=2016-12-01|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-12|last2=Pegg|first2=David|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Unaoil's litigation, in which it alleged the SFO had acted unlwafully, was dismissed by the High Court.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-court-unaoil-sfo-idUKKBN1702JS|title=UK court dismisses Unaoil case against anti-fraud agency|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=Reuters UK|access-date=2017-07-12|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In March 2016, the SFO began investigating allegations Unaoil acting corruptly in facilitating business deals involving [[Rolls-Royce Holdings|Rolls Royce]], [[KBR (company)|Halliburton-KBR]], [[Petrofac]], [[ABB Group|ABB]], Leighton Holdings and Amec Foster Wheeler.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d67341f6-6665-11e7-8526-7b38dcaef614|title=Amec Foster Wheeler Shares drop 10 per cent on SFO probe|last=Thomas|first=Natalie|date=|website=Financial Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref>
In the United States, KBR, [[FMC Technologies]] and [[Core Laboratories|Core Labs]] all disclosed in 2016 that they had been contacted by the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] in connection with a DOJ probe of Unaoil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.law360.com/articles/890990/swiss-engineering-co-admits-improper-unaoil-payments|title=Swiss Engineering Co. Admits Improper Unaoil Payments - Law360|website=www.law360.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref>
The SFO and DOJ inquiries followed media reports that Unaoil allegedly facilitated extensive corruption and bribery in the [[oil industry]].<ref name="AgeMar30Comp">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/interactive/2016/the-bribe-factory/day-1/the-company-that-bribed-the-world.html|title=The Bribe Factory: Part 1|date=2016-03-30|work= [[The Age]]|first1= Nick |last1= McKenzie |first2= Richard |last2= Baker |first3=Michael |last3= Bachelard |first4= Daniel |last4= Quinlan |accessdate=2016-03-30}}</ref> A leaked cache of Unaoil internal company emails dating from 2001 to 2012 were the subject of a series of articles published by [[Fairfax Media]] investigative reporters [[Nick McKenzie]], Richard Baker and Michael Bachelard in the Australian newspaper ''[[The Age]]'', and ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' in March 2016. Under headlines such as "Unaoil: World's Biggest Bribe Scandal"<ref name="AgeMar30Comp" /> and "Unaoil: Company that Bribed the World",<ref name="AgeMar30Comp" /> ''The Age'' wrote that "How they make their money is simple. Oil-rich countries often suffer poor governance and high levels of corruption. Unaoil's business plan is to play on the fears of large Western companies that they cannot win contracts without its help. Its operatives then bribe officials in oil-producing nations to help these clients win government-funded projects. The corrupt officials might rig a tender committee. Or leak inside information. Or ensure a contract is awarded without a competitive tender".<ref name="AgeMar30Comp" />
In Iraq, Unaoil was alleged to have paid "multi-million dollar lump sums" to senior politicians. Other oil producing countries that Unaoil have operated in include Iran, Libya, Syria, Yemen, Kuwait, and the UAE.<ref name="AgeMar30Comp" />
In March 2016 ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' published a letter from a legal representative of Unaoil in which the allegations of corruption and bribery are denied.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.smh.com.au/national/how-bribe-factory-unaoil-tried-to-stop-us-telling-their-secrets-20160331-gnutfc.html |title= How bribe factory Unaoil tried to stop us telling their secrets |work= [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |first= Michael |last= Bachelard |date= 2016-03-31 |accessdate= 2016-03-31}}</ref>
On 31 March 2016, Monaco authorities announced that they had raided the offices of Unaoil and the homes of some of its executives, following an urgent request for assistance from the UK's [[Serious Fraud Office (United Kingdom)|Serious Fraud Office]]. The statement said, "These searches and interviews were carried out in the presence of British officials as part of a vast, international corruption scandal implicating numerous foreign oil industry firms. The information collected is going to be examined by the British authorities as part of their investigation."<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/apr/01/authorities-monaco-raid-oil-firm-unaoil-hq-corruption-investigation |title= Authorities in Monaco raid oil firm HQ in corruption investigation |work= [[The Guardian]] |first= Kevin |last= Rawlinson |date= 2016-04-01 |accessdate= 2016-04-02}}</ref> The [[National Crime Agency|UK National Crime Agency]] carried out their investigation in collaboration with the [[Australian Federal Police]] and the [[FBI|U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/fbi-justice-department-unaoil_us_56fca3bbe4b0a06d5804cbae |title= FBI And Justice Department Probing Huge International Bribery Scandal |work= [[Huffington Post]] |first1= Nick |last1= McKenzie |first2= Richard |last2= Baker |first3=Michael |last3= Bachelard |first4= Daniel |last4= Quinlan |date= 2016-03-31 |accessdate= 2016-04-03}}</ref>
On 27 February 2017, an article in the [[News Corp]]-owned ''[[The Australian]]'' presented an alternative perspective on the Unaoil bribery scandal.<ref name=TheAustFeb27Comp>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/media/fairfaxs-pain-just-beginning-as-unaoil-stories-keep-taking/news-story/bbb249c15bf00f305744a60d9ef91a54|title=Fairfax’s pain just beginning as Unaoil stories keep taking |date=2017-02-27|work= [[The Australian]]|first1= Chris |last1= Merritt |accessdate=2017-03-18}}{{subscription required}}</ref> This claimed that the Fairfax Media newspapers had settled claims made against them regarding false allegations and indicated that "within weeks, the publisher will be confronted with yet another legal action, this time from the company at the centre of the allegations that triggered these backdowns. That company is Unaoil, a Monaco-based business that is a player in the international oil industry and is owned by the Ashani family." The article claimed that the leaker of the company emails was an extortionist who had hacked Unaoil, and stated that Unaoil would seek through court to identify the sources for the 2016 articles. ''[[The Australian]]'' had previously reported Unaoil's denials of the allegations, and accusation that it was the victim of extortion, on 17 May 2016.<ref name=TheAustMay17Comp>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/latest-news/unaoil-denies-media-claims-of-corruption/news-story/840ea2a1e790616ad643aac57b9229c5?nk=855e6f8221a9f4da7f7ce9a5b1ae1234-1489803463|title=Unaoil denies media claims of corruption |date=2016-05-17|work= [[The Australian]] |accessdate=2017-03-18}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Neither of these articles suggested that the content of the leaked emails upon which the earlier allegations had been based was inaccurate or forged.
In November 2016, the [[HM Treasury|UK Treasury]] announced it was giving the SFO 'blockbuster funding' to resource the agency's Unaoil probe. That same month, a former Unaoil country manager told the [[Panorama (TV series)|BBC's Panorama]] programme he had bribed a Libyan government official. The whistleblower, Lindsay Mitchell, said that in 2009 he handed an envelope filled with US dollars to a manager at a subsidiary of the state-owned Libyan National Oil Company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2016/nov/01/serious-office-given-extra-funds-to-investigate-unaoil-bribery-claims|title=Serious Fraud Office given extra funds to investigate Unaoil bribery claims|last=Pegg|first=David|date=2016-11-01|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-12|last2=Evans|first2=Rob|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|last3=Watt|first3=Holly}}</ref>
In January 2017, the DOJ announced in a [https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/rolls-royce-plc-agrees-pay-170-million-criminal-penalty-resolve-foreign-corrupt-practices-act statement] that [[Rolls-Royce Holdings|Rolls Royce]] had agreed to pay a $170 million fine to settle corruption allegations involving its use of several facilitators to win contracts, including Unaoil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/rolls-royce-plc-agrees-pay-170-million-criminal-penalty-resolve-foreign-corrupt-practices-act|title=Rolls-Royce plc Agrees to Pay $170 Million Criminal Penalty to Resolve Foreign Corrupt Practices Act Case|website=www.justice.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref>
Ongoing investigations by the UK's Serious Fraud Office were reported in April 2017.<ref>[https://www.ft.com/content/e687cada-6e93-3f71-bdba-13dc9de2cdf0 Jane Croft, (28 April 2017), UK fraud office opens probe into KBR unit, ''Financial Times'']. Retrieved 21 May 2017</ref> In May 2017, listed UK company [[Petrofac]] suspended a top executive in connection to the Unaoil investigation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2017/05/25/petrofac-suspends-top-executive-amid-sfo-corruption-probe/|title=Petrofac suspends top executive amid SFO corruption investigation|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-07-12|language=en-GB}}</ref>
=== Corruption charges laid by Serious Fraud Office === On November 17 2017, the Serious Fraud Office charged two former Unaoil Iraq managers with conspiring to pay bribes to win Dutch company SBM Offshore contracts in Iraq.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2017/nov/16/serious-office-charges-two-unaoil-executives-with-bribery|title=Serious Fraud Office charges two Unaoil executives with bribery|last=Watt|first=Holly|date=2017-11-16|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-11-17|last2=Evans|first2=Rob|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|last3=Pegg|first3=David}}</ref> The Iraq officials allegedly bribed were not named. The SFO also issued extradition proceedings against Unaoil Chief Operations Officer Saman Ahsani.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2017/nov/16/serious-office-charges-two-unaoil-executives-with-bribery|title=Serious Fraud Office charges two Unaoil executives with bribery|last=Watt|first=Holly|date=2017-11-16|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-11-17|last2=Evans|first2=Rob|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|last3=Pegg|first3=David}}</ref>

{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=War of the Two Capitals |partof= |image= |caption= |date=1328–1332 |place=[[North China]], [[Mongolia]], [[Manchuria]] |result=Khanbaliq group (restorationists) victory |territory= |combatant1=Khanbaliq group
(Restorationists) |combatant2=Shangdu group
(Loyalists) |combatant3= |commander1=[[Jayaatu Khan Tugh Temür]]
[[El Temür]] |commander2=[[Ragibagh Khan]]
[[Dawlat Shah]] |commander3= |strength1= |strength2= |strength3= |casualties1= |casualties2= |casualties3= }} The '''War of the Two Capitals''' ({{zh|t=兩都之戰|s=两都之战}}) was a [[civil war]] that occurred in 1328 under the [[Yuan dynasty]] based in [[China]]. It was a [[war of succession]] fought between the forces based in the Yuan capital [[Khanbaliq]] (Dadu, modern [[Beijing]]) and the forces based in the [[summer capital]] [[Shangdu]] after the death of Yuan emperor [[Yesün Temür (Yuan dynasty)|Yesün Temür]] in Shangdu. The clash between the two groups was the bloodiest and most destructive succession in all Yuan history. The War of the Two Capitals was less about ideology and more a struggle to advance individual family interests through political alliances and military strength.[[David M. Robinson]], ''Empire's Twilight: Northeast Asia Under the Mongols'', page 40. It ended with victory for the Khanbaliq group, but it took a few years for the last remnants of its opponents to give up. ==Background== In 1323, when [[Gegeen Khan|Shidebala Gegeen Khan]] (Emperor Yingzong) was assassinated by Grand Censor [[Tegshi]] and Esen Temur, the rebellious group welcomed Yesün Temür as the new ruler. The death of Yesün Temür Khan in [[Shangdu]] five years later in August 1328 gave the line of Khayishan [[Külüg Khan]] (Emperor Wuzong) an opportunity to surface. The designated heir, Yesün Temü's son [[Ragibagh Khan|Ragibagh]], was installed by the powerful [[Muslim]] officer and Yesün Temür's favorite retainer [[Dawlat Shah]] at the summer palace in Shangdu in the next month. At the main capital in Khanbaliq (Dadu, modern [[Beijing]]), however, bold action was taken to restore the throne to the sons of Khayishan, either [[Khutughtu Khan Kusala|Kusala]] (the father of the last Yuan ruler [[Toghon Temür]]) or [[Jayaatu Khan Tugh Temür|Tugh Temür]] (who was cooling his heels in [[South China]]).David M. Robinson, ''Empire's Twilight: Northeast Asia Under the Mongols'', page 39. But it was mainly due to the political ingenuity of [[El Temür]], whose [[Qipchaq]] family reached its zenith under Khayishan. He activated a conspiracy in the capital Khanbaliq to overthrow the court at Shangdu. He and his entourages enjoyed enormous geographical and economic advantages over the loyalists of Yesün Temür. Tugh Temür was recalled to Khanbaliq by El Temür since his more influential brother Kuśala stayed in far-away [[Central Asia]] at the time. He was installed as the new ruler in Khanbaliq in September at about the same time Ragibagh succeeded to the throne in Shangdu. Not everyone who participated in the movement had ties as close as El Temür's to Khayishan's family.Herbert Franke, Denis Twitchett, John King Fairbank, ''The Cambridge History of China: Alien regimes and border states, 907–1368'', page 542. The restorationists under El Temür had the extensive human and material resources of the Central Region (under [[Zhongshu Sheng]]), [[Hunan]], [[Jiangzhe Province|Jiangzhe]], [[Jiangxi]] and [[Huguang]] provinces whereas the loyalists at Shangdu had the support of only [[Lingbei province|Lingbei]], [[Liaoyang province|Liaoyang]], [[Shaanxi]], [[Sichuan]] and [[Yunnan]], all of which were geographically peripheral.Dardess-Conquerors and Confucians, pp.39–42 Also, Mongolian princes and high-ranking Mongolian officials based in [[Manchuria]] (Liaodong) and eastern [[Mongolia]] fought on both sides of this civil war. ==The war== At the start of the war, Ragibagh's forces broke through the [[Great Wall]] at several points, and penetrated as far as the outskirts of Khanbaliq. El Temür, however, was able to turn the tide quickly in his favor. The restorationists from Manchuria and eastern Mongolia launched a surprise attack on the loyalists. Their army under the command of Bukha Temur and Orlug Temur, descendants of [[Genghis Khan]]'s brothers, surrounded Shangdu on 14 November, at a time most of the loyalists were involved on the Great Wall front.Yuan shi, 32, pp.605 The loyalists in Shangdu surrendered on the very next day, and Dawlat Shah and most of the leading loyalists were taken prisoner and later executed. Ragibagh was reported to be missing.Frederick W. Mote, ''Imperial China 900–1800'', page 471. With the surrender of Shangdu, the way to restoring Khayishan's imperial line was cleared. However, the loyalists elsewhere carried on fighting for much longer. Indeed, the loyalists in Shanxi did not lay down their arms until December 1328, and their counterparts in Sichuan surrendered only in the following month.Herbert Franke, Denis Twitchett, John King Fairbank ''The Cambridge History of China: Alien regimes and border states, 907–1368'', page 544. Early in the next year there was a revolt in Yunnan, where the Prince Tugel declared himself independent. Troops were sent against him, and were ordered to march by the country of Pa fan. With the support of the [[Yunnan#Ethnicity|province's aboriginal tribes]], such as the Lolos and other tribes of Miaotze on the borders of Yunnan, Tugel successfully resisted the imperial army. The Yuan army under the command of Temur Buka was defeated, and sent for reinforcements. At that point the Prince Yuntu Temur was ordered to withdraw 20,000 men from the provinces of Jiangzhe, Jiangxi and Henan Jiangbei, and to lead them by way of Huguang towards Yunnan.Yuan shi, 31, pp.697 The last remnants of the loyalists did not give up their cause until 1332. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Yuan dynasty topics}} [[Category:Wars involving the Yuan dynasty]] [[Category:14th-century conflicts]] [[Category:14th century in China]] [[Category:14th century in Mongolia]] [[Category:Wars of succession]] [[Category:1320s in the Mongol Empire]] [[Category:1330s in the Mongol Empire]]

'''Yota Space''' is a non-profit international [[digital art]] festival organized by [[Yota]] in [[Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]] since 2010. [[File:Yota Space 2012 Logo.jpg|thumb|Yota Space Festival Logo]]
== The Concept == Yota Space is an international festival in [[Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]], Russia. The festival is dedicated to [[Contemporary art|contemporary]] [[Digital art|digital]] and interactive [[Digital art|art]]. Yota Space is the space of the future, an exciting creative environment, a platform for sharing experiences and knowledge. The festival is conceived as a space of creative growth and exchange of experience, a major component of the project is an [[Educational program|educational]] program.
[[File:Yota Space 2010 - Hot Chip.jpg|thumb|Hot Chip at Yota Space 2010 Grand Opening]] [[File:Yota Space 2010 - Hall.jpg|thumb|Yota Space 2010. Reception]] [[File:Yota Space 2010 - Lecture Hall.jpg|thumb|Yota Space 2010. Lecture Hall]] [[File:Yota Space 2010 - Musion Area.jpg|thumb|Yota Space 2010. Musion Area]] [[File:Yota Space 2010 - Screening Hall.jpg|thumb|Yota Space 2010. Screening Hall]]
== Yota Space 2010 == The first Yota Space festival was held in St. Petersburg December 5–19, 2010 in a giant former Stalin-era Frunzenskiy department store (Moskovsky Prospect, 60). The festival Grand Opening show was featured with a concert involving [[Hot Chip]], Masters of Skweee, D-Pulse, SCSI-9, etc. The festival received wide coverage in Russian and international<ref name="wp">[http://www.wallpaper.com/art/yota-space-digital-art-festival-st-petersburg/5020 Yota Space digital art festival], Wallpaper, 13.12.2010.</ref><ref name="ind">[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/yota-space-the-light-fantastic-2160434.html Yota Space: The light fantastic], Independent, 15.12.2010.</ref> press. [[The Financial Times]] named Yota Space "The largest digital arts festival in Europe".<ref name="test">[http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/cde72d42-0ee5-11e0-9ec3-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1XGIBWOex Smart materials], Financial Times, 30.12.2010.</ref>

== Yota Space 2012 == In Spring 2012 [[Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]] will host Yota Space International [[Digital Art]] again. During six weeks the public will be immersed in the interactive space, and transform themselves and their perceptions with new experiences and emotions. As for the first time, the festival will be filled with interactive [[Installation art|installations]], [[Kinetic art|kinetic]] and media sculptures, [[3D projection|3D-projections]], other digital art masterpieces, audio-visual [[Performance art|performances]], lectures and concerts.
=== Artists === Among the participants of Yota Space 2012 are [[:fr:Djeff|Djeff]] (France), [[LAb(au)|LAb[au]]] (Belgium), MSA Visuals (UK), Danniel Hirschman (Germany), Nordic Creative (Norway), Studio Roosergaarde (Netherlands), Zigelbaum + Coelho (USA/Brazil), Jonas Heuer (Germany), Martin Richardson & Chris Levine (UK), Lawrence Malstaf (Belgium), Felix Luque Sanchez (Spain), John Miserendino, Charles Carcopino (Italy), [[Kurt Hentschlager|Kurt Hentschläger]] (Austria / USA), Motoi Ishibashi & Daite Manabe (Japan), Russian Visuals Artists (Russia) and many others.
